intro: Absinthium rupestre, commonly known as rock wormwood, is a perennial herb native to rocky and arid regions of Europe and Asia. It features slender, branched stems that often grow in dense clusters, adapted to withstand harsh environmental conditions. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom in late summer. Its leaves are narrow and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its drought-resistant characteristics. Absinthium rupestre is often found in limestone soils and is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical use in herbal medicine.
distribution_native_art_desc: Absinthium rupestre is primarily native to southern Europe, including countries such as Spain, Portugal, and southern France. It is also found in parts of North Africa, particularly in Morocco and Algeria. This plant thrives in rocky and arid environments, often growing on limestone or sandstone substrates. It is commonly found in high-altitude regions and along coastal areas. Its distribution is closely associated with Mediterranean climate zones characterized by dry summers and mild, wet winters.
